15.19.text:
It is the bathing place of our older people,
tupuna, it's a spiritual place too, to Tuhoe,

26.49.text:
to myself, it's home.
I think as far as difference of scenery in

37.74.text:
New Zealand, Waikaremoana has amazing forest.
The botanical diversity is the most impressive

43.03.text:
in New Zealand. Great climate, impressive
bluffs, mountains, that real classic North

64.66.text:
The great walk follows the shorelines of Lake
Waikaremoana. We've got beautiful panekire

71.49.text:
that's at the head of the lake, if you like,
and it's mingled with the ancient forest.

79.42.text:
Large tracks of forest which have remained
untouched for thousands and thousands of years.

96.00.text:
[music]
I've done it once before, and spectacular.

100.93.text:
Beautiful, mind blowing. Nothing short of
amazing.

103.77.text:
Yeah, we're hoping to see a few birds, and
see some great views, as well. Just good to

108.81.text:
get time-out, you know, and escape from everything
[laughter] for a while.

113.00.text:
Yeah, not watch TV, and have no cell phone
reception for a while.

123.37.text:
[music]
Anyone who wants to get in to tramping, this

127.53.text:
would be a really good moderate level tramp.
As long as you pace yourself, I would say

132.70.text:
that anyone of a moderate fitness level would
be able to do it, and do it comfortably.

138.17.text:
Pretty amazing to be able to bring my Nanna
on this walk with, it's been her lifelong

142.22.text:
dream to walk the Waikaremoana track. And
she thought she was never going to do it.

146.09.text:
So, I suppose you could say, she took it off
her bucket list. She loved it.

167.46.text:
[music]
One of the major points of Waikaremoana, it

171.72.text:
has a real sense of history. Amazing place
and you can't help but feel there's something

175.70.text:
out there. It's an amazing place to hang out,
amazing place to be.

179.49.text:
Be prepared to get to know yourself. Know
yourself really well. The isolation allows

185.95.text:
you to drain your normal daily thoughts and
pressures, to realize who you are as a person,

196.18.text:
and that connection with the whenua. A lot
of people don't realize what that is until

200.63.text:
they experience it. And they walk away from
this kind of place with a renewed and refreshed

224.47.text: I think it's a spectacular walk to do, a lot of people do, only in one day, is the Mount Tongariro Alpine Crossing.

228.75.text:
But there's so much more to it. There's the Eastern side
of Mount Tongariro, the Tama lakes area, the

233.93.text:
Waihohonu area. And you can put all that together
as a two or three day circuit.

241.31.text:
So many different landscapes, and everything
is so close together.

245.16.text:
It was pure fresh air.
Massive tree ferns, pongas, then you've got

251.43.text:
the ice from the hills, and the snow.
[music]

257.32.text:
Certainly on the summit of Red Crater, it's
one of the most spectacular views you'll see

261.80.text:
anywhere in the world. The Emerald Lakes is
quite often the lunch stop, and then it's

268.51.text:
down into Central Crater, which again is a
flat eroded area up to the ridge on Blue Lake.

276.63.text:
Then you come through the saddle in between
Rotoponga and North Crater, and sidle round

283.63.text:
North Crater.
Nice to see it, kind of seismic, live, full

288.62.text:
colours. Something I've never seen before.
It's a spectacular place, Ketetahi.

293.56.text:
Our highest hut on the northern circuit, 1456
metres, and as you've seen today, spectacular

299.33.text:
views from this hut. It's set amongst all
the red tussock, and when the sun goes down

304.91.text:
it's golden. It's a beautiful place. It's
my favourite hut, always has been.

316.16.text:
Descending into the Oturere valley, it's quite
spectacular. It's like a moonscape. Quite

321.87.text:
a unique formation all the way through, and
lots of people write in the log book at Oturere

327.38.text:
that they've walked on the moon.
[music]

341.58.text:
It's a really nice facility. It really suits
its environment, and it's just a nice place

347.73.text:
to come to when you're tired and hungry and
cold. At night time you walk in, and the lights

353.39.text:
are on, and it's nice and warm, and yeah.
It's just a great spot.

382.40.text: Still get a tingle every time I go to certain places in the park. It's a special place and I love it.

399.35.text:
That river it was just fantastic. I haven't
had an experience like that before.

406.69.text:
It means everything. It's just the life force
of the whole place. It comes from the mountain,

425.70.text: It's good bringing tourism into the area. A lot of them we see talk about going to get a cultural experience on the

435.09.text: river. We're all for it. It's what gives us a chance to speak and show who we are. We basically try to give

442.43.text: every river user a powhiri during the end of the day just before the sun goes down we'll do one powhiri. We'll

447.27.text:
welcome everyone on the marae and our aim
is just to give everyone a little bit Whanganui-style

454.68.text:
and allow them to enjoy the beauty of this
place.

483.59.text:
We're at the Mangaparoa landing and it's along
the Wanganui journey and people normally stop

488.12.text:
here to access the bridge to nowhere.
It's just amazing to see a bridge out in the

494.53.text:
middle of nowhere.
The Mangaparoa track is actually part of the

498.32.text:
Mountain to See cycle trail as well. It's
quoted by the Kennett brothers who are the

502.69.text:
mountain bike gurus in New Zealand as "If
there's anyone adventure ride you're going

506.83.text:
to do this year this should be it".
I'm a local. I love the place so it's good

510.93.text:
to see that more and more people coming to
visit it.

525.93.text:
So we're at Mangawaiti campsite. Back in the
day a lot of Maori used to live high up in

537.27.text:
the river so they used to have their marae
and pa sites up similar to the campsite. The

546.42.text:
Wanganui journey runs right through the centre
of one of the country's biodiversity projects

551.16.text:
called Ke Wariti. The project aims to improve
forest condition and increase bird species.

557.05.text:
If people are doing the journey not only do
they get an understanding of the rich cultural

562.04.text:
landscape but they also get a good picture
of the biodiversity work happening in the

565.85.text:
area as well.
To see it up and running and starting to get

570.22.text:
a bit greener a few more of the native species
coming through and then more kiwis and blue

574.84.text:
ducks and that's what it's all about really.
It's keeping it nga hiri up and running because

579.45.text:
once we lose it that's one of the great walks
or national parks gone.

584.54.text:
The bush is looking fantastic and green and
an increase in some bird populations, kakariki

590.27.text:
and robin, and as you can see lots of fantail.
It's pretty alive at the moment.

606.97.text:
You've got really settled weather for long
periods of time. You've got native bush right

612.42.text:
down to the sea. You've got the granite rocks
with all the different shapes.

622.82.text:
[music]
It's really terrific. It's really nice. Beautiful

631.13.text:
weather. Beautiful beaches. Seals, birds.
It's one of the highlights of New Zealand.

634.93.text:
So that's why we come here.
So it's our first tramping experience, but

650.50.text:
Kayak the first day, camp out, and then hike
the second day.

654.20.text:
The beaches are amazing and had a great day
so far.

658.69.text: Absolutely stunning weather. We're loving it so far. The sun is out. We're happy.

677.60.text:
From sort of April, May, June, a fantastic
time to come here to the Abel Tasman because

683.14.text:
you've got a great change of having the beach
completely to yourself. They get to see it

716.12.text:
Everyday is really different and that's what
we really look forward to enjoying.

734.48.text: It's like a Roman road or something. It's great condition. Very comfortable. We're getting a lot of people

742.40.text:
come through and they all seem pretty happy
with it.

761.92.text: We've spent two nights out listening for grey-spotted kiwis and had pretty good success. [music]

779.30.text: They've got native bush and the Golden Downs which is all tussock and the beautiful nikau

783.78.text:
palm forests and the beaches and the river.
Well, three days of sunshine was a big highlight.

789.67.text:
The beach, first day, awesome.
Yes.

792.04.text:
Heaps of palms. It's almost like you're on
a little island sometimes.

825.30.text: It's beautiful. Everywhere you turn, there's something amazing to look at. [music]

841.10.text: It's good to start with this one, because it goes back to the point of origin,

843.60.text: and you don't need to worry about leaving your luggage.

849.60.text: It was beautiful walking along the top where the trees are very cleared. Then you get out,

854.71.text:
and it's a beautiful view, and it was all
worth it.

870.90.text: We've met people that are, for example, travelling on the South Island and they're not really tramping. They don't

878.15.text: see the beauty of it. You have to get onto the tracks into the wild to experience it.

897.78.text: I think it's good to start with the Great Walks because everything is safe, and

903.21.text: controlled, and everything. So it's a good start. [music]

907.80.text: It's good. It's the type of thing you can do on your own and you meet people. [music]

915.79.text:
It's very nice to come here and be able to
have wilderness that's still wilderness. But,

920.73.text:
at the same time, you can come to a nice hut
and have a place to stay for a reasonable

955.16.text:
Oh, it's wonderful. It's the first track I've
ever done in my life so it's a good way to

958.65.text:
start.
The scale of the mountains, the waterfalls,

968.84.text:
Yes, fantastic. Couldn't have asked for better
weather. The snow across the top. Reasonably

974.90.text:
challenging but fantastic. Great views. Great
scenery. Really good.

980.72.text:
[music]
I've got a friend who lives in Queenstown.

986.40.text:
We've spoken about it quite a few times and
I thought, "What the hell I've done lots of

989.51.text:
trekking in Australia. This is just awesome.
[music]

995.18.text:
These huts are crazy. Just awesome.
I wasn't expecting flush toilets and toilet

1005.07.text:
paper so that was pretty fancy I guess.
I was like psyched up for a real challenge

1011.35.text:
but I actually think it's a bit easier than
what I've expected.

1015.09.text:
[music]
The sights and sounds and seeing a good chunk

1020.21.text:
of New Zealand at the same time is pretty
awesome. Going up over McKinnen Pass it was

1027.30.text:
just phenomenal. It snowed yesterday morning
and then we got to go up over and It was pretty

1060.16.text:
[music] It surpasses the pamphlet, the Routeburn
is better than the pamphlet.

1068.64.text:
Most beautiful part of New Zealand. [music]
One of the great walks, isn't it? [music]

1074.09.text:
And we've heard like this is one of the best
walks in the world. It's like in the top ten,

1077.60.text:
so we thought, "Yeah, definitely want to come
down and do it while we're here." [music]

1082.64.text:
You should of been here when the fog lifted,
like we were, "Yahoo."

1090.20.text:
Oh, that was fantastic. [music]
Think it's honestly like a postcard. We've

1094.63.text:
been here a number of times but this is--
We were here just last year in Summer.

1098.73.text:
We're going to bring everybody back here.
[music].

1101.54.text:
My husband and I did the Milford Track last
year and thoroughly enjoyed it, so we thought

1107.14.text:
we'd try it again and here we are. [music]
Yes, top spot. [music]

1135.66.text:
The track's stunning. [music]
The Routeburn has more pine above the bush

1138.78.text:
line, better alpine views. [music]
The actual tracks and the huts and scenery

1149.85.text:
is fantastic.
Yeah, and the track quality is really good

1151.91.text:
too. It obviously very well maintained and
pleasure to walk on really. [music]

1158.25.text:
We just took some amazing photos up there,
it was just absolutely beautiful so I highly

1190.17.text:
We have done quite a few of the walks, and
I'd have to say it's right up there. It's

1206.26.text:
one of the best ones. It's fabulous. I guess
we're lucky, look at this weather.

1209.67.text:
It's very clean, the people are very friendly.
I think that's the attraction of an island,

1214.84.text:
you come with that sort of isolation aspect
in mind.

1220.86.text:
We'll get beautiful calm days right through
from November through to March, but even those

1229.30.text:
shoulder seasons where it all stretched through,
then come sneak in before March, October.

1231.22.text:
It's nice and quiet so you can walk the tracks
and there's not too many people there, and

1236.95.text:
right through to April.
The big beautiful rimu�s and rata, they're

1249.60.text:
just all around us. It's up in the rimu�s,
we're getting basically another forest in

1253.56.text:
itself. We've got all the epiphytes there
clinging to the tree. You can see the broadleafs,

1257.49.text:
the ferns and they just-- there's another
forest up there just growing.

1267.14.text:
On Stewart Island everybody talks about the
mud, but on the Rakiura track that's a fallacy,

1271.32.text:
because what we've done is we've gone to a
great extent to make the track hard and comfortable

1278.71.text:
to walk.
And what we've come across here is these old

1283.11.text:
steam pullers, and these were used for pulling
or lowering logs down through the bush.

1289.14.text:
It was sort of on dusk, and Peter spotted
these two kiwis, and it was just and awesome

1296.58.text:
experience.
We've done a lot of walks and we've never

1299.04.text:
seen a kiwi in the wild. We've seen them in
captivity but never in the wild. It's something

1303.62.text:
everybody wants to do. I mean, you go on a
tramp in the hope that you're going to see

1308.27.text:
something quite unique, and you know, we scored
on this occasion, so it was fantastic.

1312.87.text:
And the fun was going out there just on darkness
and were we going to see one or when we going

1318.70.text: to see one and then we did and it was awesome.
